remarks: If a statement holds for 1 and also holds for a successor, it holds for all positive integers.  The first three hypotheses give us the substitution instances we need; the last two show that it holds for 1 and for a successor.  (Contributed by NM, 11-Oct-2004.)  (Revised by Mario Carneiro, 16-May-2014.)
statement:
nn1suc.1 $e |- ( x = 1 -> ( ph <-> ps ) ) $.
nn1suc.3 $e |- ( x = ( y + 1 ) -> ( ph <-> ch ) ) $.
nn1suc.4 $e |- ( x = A -> ( ph <-> th ) ) $.
nn1suc.5 $e |- ps $.
nn1suc.6 $e |- ( y e. NN -> ch ) $.
nn1suc $p |- ( A e. NN -> th ) $.
$d A x y $.
$d ch x $.
$d ph y $.
$d ps x $.
$d th x $.
